data.title: Show your signature model geetars…
data.meta_description:
Well it's Kanji so many Japanese people may not know it.



The tech knew what it meant and told George Lynch on the spot.  I cannot fathom having a...
data.text:
I heard he got his Phoenix back after it was lost in a plane crash , he thought it had burned up , but someone got it and never returned it until years later , I think Gibson rebuilt it for him.

Yes, that's very true. He has told that story in many, many interviews. He had previously worked with Tom Holmes on pickups while the Phenix was missing. And while Gibson worked to get it playable for him again, he put Tom's pickups in it, and they're still in it today, according to some interviews he has given.

This is the story of the guitar from Peter's own YouTube channel.

I’m not a tone chaser, nor do I try to emulate my geetar hero’s, but I have accumulated a couple signature geetars…

Sometimes I wasn’t even sure who the artist was/is but the guitar has the features I want…

I didn’t realize how many I have/have had…

what do you have tucked away?

First and foremost I have a Yngwie Malmsteen strat, I am really not a fan of strats, but this one is too cool not to have..

one of my most favorite and most played geetars.. Joe Strummer Tele

Bonamassa Firebird..

Jeff Beck unofficial sig models..

89 Charvel Spectrum..

Jackson SLX4 (spectrum replica)

93 strat plus (no longer own) not a strat fan..

Joan Jett Olympic… just love DC geetars..

Jared James Nichols LP and the Gibson BFG was inspired by a Gary Moore sig model.. didn’t know who JJN was when I decided to get one… I know who Gary Moore is..

I no longer have these…

Justin Meldal-Johnsen Mustang bass.. not a 7ender bass fan..

Sting Signature Precision Bass, again, not a fan of 7ender style basses, but this one made me appreciate the single coil pbass pickup..

Frank Iero Wilshire, I have always wanted a Wilshire, but prefer the early version with the shorter top horn… another instance of not knowing who the artist is/was

Buck Owens tele, and a custom job inspired by it

Bonamassa Amos, didnt gel with it and sold it to a friend

Tony Franklin Pbass, probably the finest built instrument I have ever held, but don’t get along with 7enders…

Great thread! Signature models are not my thing; however, if I were to get one, this would be it:

LPCAxALRby--epiphone-alex-lifeson-les-paul-custom-axcess-electric-guitar-ruby

Alex is my favorite guitar player and this one seems quite well made and versatile. Needless to say, I should have purchased the Gibson version when it came out, because the prices are now absurd:

Gibson Custom Shop Alex Lifeson Les Paul Axcess | Reverb

The Gibson Les Paul Axcess Alex Lifeson is a Custom Shop model built to the specs of the Rush guitarist. It features push-pull volume pots and a Floyd Rose style tremolo with exposed humbuckers. The nitrocellulose finish comes in either Royal Crimson or Viceroy Brown Sunburst. The first 25 o...

But, if I were to get one of these two guitars, my preference would be for the Epiphone, rather than the Gibson. Why? Well, I'm not really a guitar collector; the ones in my stable are the ones used regularly. I wouldn't want to get a guitar just to hang on the wall. These are meant to be played! So the Epiphone would be a rehearsal and gigging guitar, not just a pretty face...

Yes, that's very true. He has told that story in many, many interviews. He had previously worked with Tom Holmes on pickups while the Phenix was missing. And while Gibson worked to get it playable for him again, he put Tom's pickups in it, and they're still in it today, according to some interviews he has given.

This is the story of the guitar from Peter's own YouTube channel.

I heard he uses the standard set-H450-H455 -Alnico 2-in the neck and bridge, and he uses Toms A4-H453, in the middle position.

I had a 59 Burst replica made 9 years ago, and the H450-H455 pickups, will never come out. Ive got 2 more sets that have never been installed, and just got back on Toms waiting list again. 1 year wait. 1st time I waited 20 months, because Tom almost died, and wound very few pickups during that time.

He used to wind an H453 set, upon request. I think they are something like 7.4k, and both have the same reading. I just may see if he will still wind a set of those, when my # comes up.

Gary Moore, also helped Tom work on those pickups, as did Billy Gibbons. Gary Moore, was Toms best friend, is what Tom told me.

Garys Custom Shop Les Paul, had Toms H450-H455, installed from Gibson.

I heard he uses the standard set-H450-H455 -Alnico 2-in the neck and bridge, and he uses Toms A4-H453, in the middle position.

I had a 59 Burst replica made 9 years ago, and the H450-H455 pickups, will never come out. Ive got 2 more sets that have never been installed, and just got back on Toms waiting list again. 1 year wait. 1st time I waited 20 months, because Tom almost died, and wound very few pickups during that time.

He used to wind an H453 set, upon request. I think they are something like 7.4k, and both have the same reading. I just may see if he will still wind a set of those, when my # comes up.

Gary Moore, also helped Tom work on those pickups, as did Billy Gibbons. Gary Moore, was Toms best friend, is what Tom told me.

Garys Custom Shop Les Paul, had Toms H450-H455, installed from Gibson.

Tom is awesome. I have my Frampton with the same H450/H453/H455 set Peter uses, unpotted. I have a beautiful LP Standard T Fireburst with H450/H455 as well. I've thought about ordering more, but haven't.

I also have two Classic Custom's, a 2011 and 2012. They have the '57 Classic's set. They're from before Gibson deviated from Tom's original design he did for them. They are fantastic themselves. So, technically, I would say, I have four Gibson Les Paul's with Tom's pickups. Love them all.
